title: Pleurocera
text:
Pleurocera is a <a href="genus">genus</a> of <a href="freshwater%20snail">freshwater snail</a>s with an <a href="operculum%20%28gastropod%29">operculum</a>, <a href="aquatic%20animal">aquatic</a> <a href="gastropod">gastropod</a> <a href="mollusk">mollusk</a>s in the family <a href="Pleuroceridae">Pleuroceridae</a>.
"Pleurocera" is the <a href="type%20genus">type genus</a> of that family.
Distribution.
All members of the genus "Pleurocera" are native to eastern <a href="North%20America">North America</a>.
Description.
All of the species in this genus have thick-walled high-<a href="Spire%20%28mollusc%29">spired</a> shells, and some attain a length of over 4 cm. The shape of the <a href="gastropod%20shell">shell</a> is elongate-conic or cylindrical. The <a href="Sculpture%20%28mollusc%29">sculpture</a> of the shell is often carinate or costate. The shell of larger species sometimes develops sculpturing and a small <a href="siphonal%20canal">siphonal canal</a> or <a href="siphonal%20notch">siphonal notch</a> at the base of the <a href="Aperture%20%28mollusc%29">aperture</a>.
<a href="Operculum%20%28gastropod%29">Opercula</a> are paucispiral and <a href="corneous">corneous</a>, but may be <a href="vestigiality">vestigial</a> in some species, not completely closing the aperture.
The soft parts of the animal usually have a gray or brown coloration, commonly speckled with orange. The similar genus "<a href="Juga">Juga</a>" has a <a href="seminal%20receptacle">seminal receptacle</a>, but "Pleurocera" has no seminal receptacle.
Species.
Species within the genus "Pleurocera" include: (brackets needs to be checked, authorities according to the IUCN Red List may be incorrect)
Ecology.
Most species inhabit larger <a href="river">river</a>s.
"Pleurocera" snails are <a href="dioecious">dioecious</a>.
